title: Trek launches new Checkpoint gravel bike with progressive geometry and frame storage
content:
Trek has revamped its Checkpoint line-up, with the updated gravel bike coming in not one but three different flavours, covering the needs of go-fast racers, rough-and-ready adventurers and riders looking for a versatile N+1.

The range starts off with the carbon fibre Checkpoint SLR. It’s designed to be light and fast, with aero-influenced tube profiles inspired by the latest Trek Emonda. It’s geared towards the newest niche of gravel bike racing.

There’s then the carbon Checkpoint SL, which is pitched at the long-distance gravel rider covering technical terrain, though still with an eye on racing.

The Checkpoint SLR features Trek’s latest top tube IsoSpeed, while the second-tier Checkpoint SL uses the well-proved seat tube IsoSpeed. Both have front IsoSpeed.

Finally, there’s the aluminium Checkpoint ALR, aiming to be an off-road all-rounder that can also work as a commuting bike.

In all, there are eight Checkpoint models at launch plus two frameset-only options.

Progressive gravel geometry

Trek has updated the geometry of the new Checkpoint.

Like modern mountain bikes, gravel bikes are getting longer and slacker to improve control.

Increasing the frame’s reach while shortening the stem can improve control on steep terrain as you are less pitched over the front wheel. Slackening out the front-end can also improve stability at high speeds.

With this in mind, the Checkpoint now has a 20mm longer front-centre than the outgoing bike. The bikes are also now specced with shorter stems across the board.

On top of that, chainstay length has been increased to 435mm across all sizes, increasing the bike’s wheelbase, which can also improve stability.

Wide tyres and all the storage

Trek

The new Checkpoint has clearance for 45mm tyres on 700c wheels or 2.1in tyres on 650b wheels.

All the bikes use Trek’s T47 threaded bottom bracket standard for ease-of-use and compatibility.

Trek

As you’d expect for a gravel bike, there are tons of mounting points, including scope for four bottle cages on the larger-sized frames: two on the top of the down tube, one on the underside of the down tube, and one of the seat tube.

Trek has also launched a complete set of bikepacking bags to go with the new range.

Trek

The carbon fibre Checkpoint SLR and SL frames also feature integrated storage in the down tube.

Trek Checkpoint SLR

Trek

The Checkpoint SLR frameset is made of 700 Series OCLV carbon and comes with a seatmast rather than a conventional seatpost.

That means you can’t fit a dropper post – you need to move down to the second-tier SL if you want the option to add a dropper.

The frame features Trek’s top tube IsoSpeed to improve comfort, as found on the Domane SLR and Madone SLR. In this design, the L-shaped seatmast is braced by the top tube, with an elastomer to add damping.

Trek

However, unlike the Domane and Madone, the new Checkpoint SLR’s top tube IsoSpeed isn’t adjustable – instead the amount of flex is fixed and scaled by frame size.

The Checkpoint SLR is available at four spec levels, topping out with the £11,000 ($12,000 / €12,000 / AU$16,500) Checkpoint SLR 9 eTap, decked out in SRAM’s top-spec wireless Red/XPLR groupset and Bontrager Aeolus RSL 37 carbon wheels. Claimed weight is 8.1kg.

Trek

Below the SLR 9 eTap, there’s the SLR 7 eTap (£7,800) which comes with a SRAM Force eTap AXS 1×12-speed groupset, the SLR 7 (£7,650) with Shimano GRX RX815 2×11-speed Di2 and the  SLR 6 eTap (£6,450) with 1×12-speed SRAM Rival eTap AXS.

All the Checkpoint SLR models below the Checkpoint SLR 9 eTap come with 25mm internal width Bontrager Aeolus Pro 3V carbon wheels. 

Trek Checkpoint SL

Trek

The Checkpoint SL frame is made from 500 Series OCLV carbon and has a conventional seatpost, rather than the seatmast of the SLR, meaning it is compatible with a dropper post.

Trek’s seat tube IsoSpeed is deployed on the Checkpoint SL. Here, a decoupler isolates the seat tube from the top tube, allowing it to flex independently.

The Checkpoint SL comes in three specs. Top dog is the Checkpoint SL 7 eTap, priced at £5,750 ($6,300 / €6,000 / AU$8,000).

It’s kitted out with a SRAM Force eTap AXS Wide 2×12-speed groupset and Bontrager Aeolus Pro 3V carbon wheels. Claimed weight is 8.9kg.

Below the SL7 eTap comes the SL 6 eTap with a SRAM Rival eTap AXS 1×12-speed groupset (£3,750) and finally the SL 5 with Shimano GRX 2×11-speed mechanical groupset (£3,200). Both of these specs drop to alloy wheels.

There’s also the option to buy the SL frameset.

Trek Checkpoint ALR

Trek

Finally, the alloy Checkpoint ALR comes in just one spec, the ALR 5, priced at £2,250 ($2,400 /  €2,399 / AU$3,200). There’s a frameset-only option, too.

The frame is made from 300 Series Alpha aluminum, while the fork has an alloy steerer, rather than the all-carbon number of the higher-spec bikes.

The Checkpoint ALR comes with a 2×11-speed Shimano GRX mechanical groupset with RX600 shifters operating RX810-series derailleurs.

A 46/30t chainset is paired with an 11-34t cassette, for plenty of low range grunt. Trek claims a weight of 9.75kg.

Availability of the new Checkpoint is immediate, both online and via retailers.

  • Fork: Checkpoint carbon
  • Groupset: SRAM Red eTap AXS 1×12-speed/ SRAM Red XPLR rear derailleur

  • Brakes: SRAM Red eTap AXS HRD
  • Wheels: Bontrager Aeolus RSL 37 carbon
  • Tyres: Bontrager GR1 Team Issue, 40mm
  • Bar: Bontrager Pro IsoCore VR-SF
  • Stem: Bontrager RSL carbon
  • Saddle: Bontrager P3 Verse Pro, carbon rail
  • Seatpost: Bontrager carbon seatmast cap, 5mm offset
  • Sizes: 49cm, 52 cm, 54cm, 56cm, 58cm, 61cm
  • Claimed weight: 8.1kg
